Simply edit GitHub Pages

This page was automatically generated using GitHub Pages and modified to add support for the Vedor editor. This editor uses the markup provided in the HTML to merge the page with the data, clientside. In this example, the page data is also stored in GitHub.

Not just Markdown

While Markdown is fine for most uses, this editor allows you to fully leverage the power of HTML. By using <template> instructions within the HTML, the editor can insert any HTML structure you want. Modifications on the page are quick and simple, leaving you in control. Take a peek at the quick integration guide for more information

Plays well with others

This editor was designed with an expanding web in mind. The toolbars in the pages are context-aware and are easily added to the editor to add specific options for specific HTML structures. The basic version supports the most commonly used HTML elements (text, images, hyperlinks), but more toolbars are available. Each editor context uses CSS-like selectors to decide which toolbar is best suited. 

CMS Integrations

We are looking for developers that want to help us integrate the Vedor editor into various platforms. We have integrated the editor in Ariadne, our own web application platform, but the world of the web is a much larger place. Since the editor is now totally decoupled from Ariadne, we want to share it with as many users as possible.

Support or Contact

Having trouble with the editor? Have an idea for a 'must have' plugin? Drop me a line here on GitHub.

Simply-edit is maintained by ylebre. This page was generated by GitHub Pages using the Cayman theme by Jason Long.

/simply-edit/integration.html.project-tagline: How to deploy the Vedor editor on your site
/simply-edit/integration.html.main-content:
How to deploy the editor on your site

Here is a quick integration guide to add the Vedor editor to your own website. You will need some experience with HTML for this, although we tried really hard to make this as simple as possible. 

Lets say you have a heading in your page. The HTML will look something like this: 
<h1>This is my title</h1> 
We need to give the editor a hint that this should be editable, and what the contents are, like so: 
<h1 data-vedor-field="title">This is my title</h1> 
Repeat this for all the elements you want to make editable.

Include the editor javascript just before the </body> tag:
<script src="http://se-cdn.muze.nl/simply-edit.js" data-api-key="github"></script>

Repeating elements and templates

In most HTML templates you will encounter repeating elements, for instance a menu or a list of blog posts. There elements all share the same HTML structure. For example: 
<ul class="posts">
  <li class="post">
    <h3>The title of the post</h3>
    <p>This is the description</p>
  </li>
</ul>

We want to tell the editor that we have a lists of posts, and that each post within the list should have the same HTML structure. Each list item has an editable title and description:
<ul class="posts" data-vedor-list="posts">
  <template data-vedor-template="Post">
    <li class="post">
      <h3 data-vedor-field="title">
      <p data-vedor-field="description">This is the description</p>
    </li>
  </template>
</ul> 

Vedor editor vocabulary

data-vedor-field=name This is editable.
data-vedor-path=/simply-edit/ Store the data within a specific path. This allows you to have fields that have the same contents across pages. 
data-vedor-type=text Applies to fields. This field contains plain text (no HTML). 
data-vedor-list=name This is a list, data for the list entries will be stored as 'name' 
data-vedor-template=name Applies on <template> tags, used to provide a list with an HTML template for list entries
data-vedor-sortable Applies to lists, makes it sortable
data-vedor-selectable Tells the editor that this element is selectable as a unit data-vedor-list-item Tells the editor that this element is an entry in a list
